emphasis.docTitle:
Three species of
Amanita section Lepidella
(
Amanitaceae
,
Agaricales
) from northern Thailand

subSection.paragraph:
YUAN S . LIU
1,2,7 , JATURONG KUMLA 1,3,8 , NAKARIN SUWANNARACH 1,3,9 , PHONGEUN SYSOUPHANTHONG 4,5,10 & SAISAMORN LUMYONG 1,3,6,11 *

subSection.paragraph:
7

*Correspondence: Saisamorn Lumyong ( � scboi009@gmail.com)

The genus
Amanita
, comprising three subgenera and eleven sections, is one of the most species diverse genera within the class
Agaricomycetes
. To date, 54 species have been validly reported from Thailand . During surveys of macro-fungi in northern Thailand in 2019 and 2020, three
Amanita species
were collected and identified as the members of
Amanita sect. Lepidella
based on morphological and molecular data. Among the three species, two species were identified as
A. aureofloccosa
and
A. manicata
and
A. aureofloccosa
is reported as a new record in Thailand . Interestingly, the third species was distinct from all other known species within sect.
Lepidella
. We describe the third species as a new species, namely
A. albicarnosa
. All these three taxa are documented with morphological characteristics, a phylogenetic tree, line drawings, color photographs, and comparisons with morphologically similar taxa. A distributional map of the sampling sites and a key to the Thai species of
Amanita sect. Lepidella
are also provided.

Key words: 1 new species,
Amanitaceae
, Phylogeny, Saprotrophic
Amanita
, Taxonomy, Tropical area

Lepidella E.J. Gilb.
, was first described as a new genus to aggregate the
Amanita species
having the strongly lepiotoid habit from
Lepiota species
( Gilbert 1925 ). Shortly afterward, Beauseigneur (1926) listed his subgenus as “
Lepidella Gilbert
”. Veselý (1933) reduced Gilbert’s genus
Lepidella
to the subgeneric rank. However, the generic name
Lepidella
was subsequently proved to be illegitimate because it was a later homonym of
Lepidella Tiegh.
(
Loranthaceae
). Although Gilbert proposed a new generic name
Aspidella E. J. Gilb. ( Gilbert 1940 )
to replace
Lepidella
, neither the former genus nor the latter genus have been generally accepted. With the exhaustive morphological study, Corner & Bas (1962) , and Bas (1969) sifted the generic classification of
Amanita
and divided it into two subgenera and six sections, of which the subgen.
Lepidella (E. J. Gilb.) Veselý emend. Corner & Bas
includes four sections (sect.
Amidella (E. J. Gilbert) Konrad & Maubl.
, sect.
Lepidella Corner & Bas
, sect. Phalloideae (Fr.) Quél., and sect. Validae (Fr.) Quél.).
Redhead et al . (2016)
proposed a new generic name
Saproamanita Redhead, Vizzini, Drehmel & Contu.
to replace both
Lepidella
and
Aspidella
. However, this propose was not or scarcely accepted by other mycologists (
Tulloss et al . 2016
;
Cui et al . 2018
;
Cui et al . 2021
,
Codjia et al . 2022
). Significantly, subgen.
Lepidella
became available after it was adapted to the subgeneric level. Based on multigene phylogenetic and morphological data,
Cui et al . (2018)
proposed to divide the genus
Amanita
into three subgenera and eleven sections (subgen.
Amanita Pers.
, containing: sect.
Amanita Pers.
, sect. Amarrendiae (Bougher & T. Lebel) Zhu L. Yang, Y.Y. Cui, Q . Cai & L.P. Tang, sect. Caesareae Singer ex Singer and sect.
Vaginatae (Fr.) Quél
; subgen.
Amanitina (E. J. Gilbert) E. J. Gilbert
, containing: sect.
Amidella
, sect. Arenariae Zhu L. Yang, Y.Y. Cui & Q . Cai, sect. Phalloideae , sect. Roanokenses Singer ex Singer, sect. Strobiliformes Singer ex Q . Cai, Zhu L. Yang & Y.Y. Cui and sect. Validae , and subgen.
Lepidella Beauseigneur
, containing sect.
Lepidella
only).

Amanita
is a widespread basidiomycetous genus comprising large numbers of both edible and poisonous species all over the world. Located in the tropical region, coupled with the seasonal climate and complex topography have resulted in huge
Amanita
resources in Thailand (
Suwannarach et al . 2022
). However, the knowledge of the genus
Amanita
in this country is limited. In the present study, we document two species,
A. albicarnosa
and
A. aureofloccosa
, which have raised the number of Thai saprotrophic
Amanita
and Thai
Amanita
to three and 56, respectively (
Boonmee et al . 2021
;
Liu et al . 2022
;
Suwannarach et al . 2022
).

Basidiomata of the fresh specimens were collected from the rice stubble field, meadows or the deciduous forest in Chiang Rai and Chiang Mai provinces, Thailand . The morphological information such as location, forest type , substrate type , and field photographs were recorded. The fresh basidiomata were dried at 35–45°C at least for twelve hours ( Zhang & Yang 2004 ) and later deposited in the Herbarium of the Biology Department, Faculty of Science, Chiang Mai University (CMUB), Chiang Mai , Thailand .

Macroscopic characteristics were described based on field notes and digital images. Color codes and abbreviations were recorded according to Kornerup & Wanscher (1978) . Microscopic features were obtained from dried materials mounted in 5% aqueous KOH (w/v), 1% Congo red (w/v) and Melzer’s reagent under a Leica DM500 microscope. For the description of basidiospores, the notation [n/m/p] refers to n basidiospores were measured from m basidiomata of p collections. Dimensions for basidiospores are given as (a–) b–c (–d) in which ‘b–c’ represents a minimum of 90% of the measured and extreme values and ‘a’ and ‘d’ are given in parentheses whenever necessary. Q denotes the ratio of length divided by the width of the basidiospore in the side view, Qm denotes the average Q of n measured basidiospores and SD is their standard deviation. Results are presented as
Q
= Qm ± SD. Marginal striations on the pileus are expressed as a proportion of the ratio of striation length to the radius of the pileus (nR). The terms referring to the size of basidiomata and spores shape are adopted according to the definitions of Bas (1969) and Yang (2015) .

heading.emphasis: DNA extraction, PCR amplification and sequencing

subSection.paragraph:
Methods of DNA extraction and PCR amplification were followed on the basis of
Cai et al . (2016)
and
Liu et al . (2021)
. Five DNA gene fragments were sequenced, including the internal transcribed spacer region (ITS), the large subunit of the nuclear ribosomal DNA (nrLSU), the partial sequences of the RNA polymerase II second largest subunit ( RPB2 ), translation elongation factor 1-alpha (
TEF 1-α
) and beta-tubulin gene (
TUB
). Sequences generated in this study were subjected to BLASTn (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov) analysis and submitted to GenBank.

Detailed information about sequences retrieved from GenBank and the sequences newly generated in this study were provided in Table 1 . Phylogenetic analysis was carried out based on only the nrLSU and ITS sequences because the amount of available sequence data in the RPB2 ,
TEF 1-α
, and
TUB
genes for the selected species are practically limited. Sequences for each single gene were separately aligned with MAFFT v.7 ( Katoh & Standley 2013 ) using the G-INSi iterative refinement algorithm, and then checked visually and manually optimized using AliView v.1.28 ( Larsson 2014 ). Gblocks v. 0.91b ( Castresana 2000 ) was used to check and exclude the ambiguously aligned regions for ITS, selecting two options “Allow smaller final blocks” and “Allow gap positions within the final blocks”. Sequence Matrix v.100.0 was applied to combine the two gene fragments for further phylogenetic analysis. The best-fit model of nucleotide substitution was determined for each single gene dataset by using MrModeltest v. 2.3 ( Nylander 2004 ) following the default parameters. Phylogenetic tree inference was performed using both Bayesian inference (BI) and maximum likelihood (ML), as detailed in
Dissanayake et al . (2020)
.

caption.paragraph: TABLE 1. Species names, voucher numbers, countries and their respective GenBank accession numbers of the taxa used in this study.

paragraph.tableNote: Newly generated sequences in this study are in black bold.

subSection.paragraph:
A total of ten specimens of
Amanita subgen. Lepidella
were obtained from northern Thailand ( Figure1 ). Morphologically, three specimens (SDBR-STO-2020-PS38, SDBR-STO-2020-PS39 & SDBR-CMUNK1470) and four specimens (SDBR-STO-2019-347, SDBR-STO-2019-390, SDBR-STO-2020-34 & SDBR-STO-2020-36) shared the same morphological characteristics with
A. aureofloccosa
and
A. manicata
, respectively. However, the morphological characteristics of the other three saprobic specimens (CMUB-39971, SDBR-STO-2020-01 & SDBR-STO-2020-04) differed from any other previously known species in
Amanita subgen. Lepidella
. These three specimens probably represent a potential new species. Therefore, the identification of all these specimens was then further confirmed by phylogenetic analyses.

The optimizing models for both nrLSU and ITS were General Time Reversible + Proportion Invariant + Gamma (GTR + I + G). The nrLSU-ITS dataset was partitioned into two parts by sequence regions. The two-gene (nrLSUITS) dataset, including the most available species of subgenus
Lepidella
, comprised 80 sequences that represented 21 species, and it contained 1,876 positions (nrLSU: 1–898; ITS: 899–1,876) after alignment.
Limacella bangladeshana CMU-JK
0146, CMU-NK0356 and HKAS 75316 were set as the outgroup. RAxML and Bayesian analysis for nrLSUITS dataset appeared largely similar in topologies of phylogenetic reconstructions. Therefore, only the result of the maximum likelihood tree is shown ( Figure 2 ).

Our optimized two-gene tree showed similar phylogenetic positions with the single-gene tree. The putative new species clustered together with
Amanita inopinata
D. A . Reid & Bas ( Reid 1987 ),
A. pruittii
A . H. Sm. ex Tulloss, J . Lindgr. & Arora (
Tulloss et al . 2014
),
A. quitensis E. Caicedo
, A . Barili, C.W. Barnes & Ordoñez (
Crous et al . 2018
), and
A. singer Bas ( Bas 1969 )
, and all these species formed a monophyletic clade with the high support (BS = 100% and PP = 1.0). Moreover, three collections representing
A. albicarnosa
presented as a well-supported distinct lineage (BS = 100% and PP = 1.0) which can be identified as a distinct species. The collections of SDBR-STO-2020-PS38 and SDBR-STO-2020-PS39 clustered together with
A. aureofloccosa
present as a well-supported distinct lineage (BS = 100% and PP = 1.0) which can be identified as a new record of
A. aureofloccosa
. Five collections of
A. manicata
from Thailand and other two samples from America and New Zealand formed a monophyletic lineage.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Fresh basidiomata of the studied
Amanita species
and location of the sampling sites. a–b:
A. albicarnosa
(CMUB-39971, holotype). c:
A. aureofloccosa
(SDBR-STO-2020-PS39). d:
A. manicata
(SDBR-STO-2020-34). e: Location of the sampling sites. Scale bars: a–b=3 cm, c=8 cm, d=5 cm.

paragraph.heading:
Amanita albicarnosa Yuan S. Liu & S. Lumyong
sp. nov.
Figure 1a, 1b and 3

subSubSection.paragraph: MycoBank number: 844132

Etymology:
albicarnosa
, from albus = whitish, and carnosus = flesh-colored, refers to the white pileus and fleshcolored lamellae of this species.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype : THAILAND . Chiang Rai Province : Mueang District , Nang Lae , N 20°01’32’’ , E 99°52’19’’ , alt.
397 m
,
2 May 2020
, Yuan S. Liu , STO-2020-003 (CMUB-39971, GenBank accession no.: nrLSU = ON695876 , ITS = ON695869 , RPB2 = ON704631 ,
TEF1 -α
= ON704634 and
TUB
= ON704637 ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis:
Amanita albicarnosa
is recognized by having small to medium-sized basidiomata; a white to yellowish white pileus covering floccose to patchy or felted, white to pale yellow volval remnants; a subcylindrical stipe coving fibrillose white scales, and a fugacious subapical annulus, as well as the present clamp.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2 . RAxML tree based on nrLSU-ITS dataset. Bootstrap values (BS) for ML ≥ 50% and posterior probabilities (PP) for BI ≥ 0.95 are placed above or below the branches respectively. Newly generated sequences are indicated in red. The tree is rooted with
Limacella bangladeshana
(CMU-JK0146, CMU-NK0356 & HKAS 75316).

subSubSection.paragraph: Description: Basidiomata small to medium-sized. Pileus 2.4–5.3 cm diam., convex to applanate, white (1A1) to yellowish white (4A2); volval remnants on pileus floccose to patchy or felted, white (1A1) to pale yellow (4A3), densely arranged on the disk; margin non-striate; context white, unchanging. Lamellae free, crowded, white (1A1) to orange white (5A2); lamellulae attenuate. Stipe 4.1–9.1×0.6–1.0 cm (length includes bulb), subcylindrical and slightly tapering upward, with apex slightly expanded, white (1A1) to pale yellow (4A3), coving fibrillose white (1A1) scales; context fistulose, white (1A1); basal bulb not obvious, sometimes fusiform or ventricose, 0.8–1.2cm diam., covering fibrillose, white (1A1) to pale yellow (4A3) volval remnants. Annulus superior, fragile, white (1A1). Odor not recorded.

Lamellar trama bilateral. Mediostratum 10–25 μm wide, composed of abundant clavate to fusiform inflated cells (30–75 × 6–11 μm); filamentous hyphae fairly abundant to abundant, 1–4 μm wide; vascular hyphae scarce. Lateral stratum 10–30 μm wide, composed of abundant clavate to sub-cylindrical inflated cells (35–65 × 5–13 μm), diverging at an angle of ca. 30° to 45° to mediostratum; filamentous hyphae fairly abundant, 3–5 μm wide. Subhymenium 10–25 μm thick, with 2–3 layers of subglobose, pyriform, or irregular cells, 8–17 × 7–13 μm. Basidia ( Figure 3b ) 40–50 × 8.5–13 μm, clavate, 4-spored; sterigmata 2–3.5 μm long; basal septa clamped. Basidiospores ( Figure 3a ) [100/3/2] (6) 7–9 (9.5) × 5–7 μm, avl X avw = 8.0 × 6.0 μm, Q = 1.15–1.55(1.70) μm, Qm = 1.34 ± 0.12, broadly ellipsoid to ellipsoid, amyloid, orange white, thin-walled, smooth; apiculus small. Pileipellis 90–145 μm thick, composed of radial, thin-walled, greyish yellow to dark yellow, filamentous hyphae 4–10 μm wide; vascular hyphae scarce. Volval remnants on pileus ( Figure 3c ) composed of irregularly arranged elements: filamentous hyphae scattered to abundant, 3–8 μm wide, light brown to yellowish brown, thin-walled, branching, anastomosing; inflated cells very abundant to dominant, subglobose, pyriform, clavate to fusiform, sometimes irregular, 33–150 × 8–28 μm, thin-walled; vascular hyphae scarce. Volval remnants on stipe base is semblable with the structure of volval remnants on pileus, filamentous hyphae scattered to abundant, 1–7 μm wide, thin-walled, branching, anastomosing; inflated cells very abundant to dominant, ellipsoid, clavate to sub-cylindrical, 23–135 × 8–32 μm, thin-walled; vascular hyphae scarce. Stipe trama composed of longitudinally arranged elements: filamentous hyphae dominant, 3–14 μm wide; inflated cells fairly abundant, ellipsoid, clavate to sub-cylindrical, 70–130 × 12–28 μm; vascular hyphae scarce. Clamps present in all parts of basidiomata.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3.
Amanita albicarnosa
(CMUB-39971, holotype). a: Basidiospores. b: Hymenium and subhymenium. c: Longitudinal section of volval remnants on pileus. Bars: a=5 μm, b=40 μm, c=40 μm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Habitat: Solitary to scattered in the rice stubble field. Basidiomata occur at the beginning of the rainy season, April to May.
Distribution: Currently known from northern Thailand ( Chiang Rai Province ).

Additional collections examined: THAILAND . Chiang Rai Province : Mueang District , N 20°01’32’’ , E 99°52’19’’ , alt.
397 m
,
2 May 2020
, Yuan S. Liu , STO-2020-001 (SDBR- STO-2020-001, GenBank accession no.: nrLSU = ON695875 , ITS = ON695868 , RPB2 = ON704630 ,
TEF1 -α
= ON704633 and
TUB
= ON704636 ); STO-2020-004 (SDBR- STO-2020-004, GenBank accession No.: nrLSU = ON695877 , ITS = ON695870 , RPB2 = ON704632 ,
TEF1 - α
= ON704635 and
TUB
= ON704638 )
.

Remarks: Our phylogenetic analyses ( Figure 2 ) showed that
Amanita albicarnosa
is closely related to
A. inopinata
,
A. pruittii
,
A. quitensis
and
A. singer
. However,
A. Amanita inopinata
has a larger cap entirely covered with the thick, cottony, pale gray-brown felt which disrupts into very prominent darker pyramidal warts ( Reid 1987 );
Amanita pruittii
has a very small to very large cap (2.0–15.0 cm) and much longer and wider stipe (3.0–15.0 × 6.0–4.0 cm), appears to be much stronger than
A. albicarnosa (
Tulloss et al . 2014
)
;
Amanita quitensis (
Crous et al. 2018
)
was firstly reported from Ecuador and this species appears under thick, dense, hard, scale-shaped warts on its white pileus, as well as the globose or rarely subglobose basidiospores (6.0–12.0 × 6.5–9.5 μm, Q = 1.04 μm);
Amanita singer
, originally described from Argentina , has the white to greyish white pileus, the rather inconspicuous volva remnants on the cap and the particular salmon-colored gills ( Bas 1969 ).

paragraph.heading:
Amanita aureofloccosa Bas, Persoonia
5: 384 (1969). Figure 1c and 4

subSubSection.paragraph:
Basionym:
Lepiota aurea Beeli
, Bull. Soc. Roy. Bot. Belg. 59: 105. 1927
; non
Amanita aurea (Beeli) E. J. Gilbert, Iconogr. Mycol.
27: 205. 1941 (=
Amanitopsis aurea Beeli, Bull. Soc. Roy. Bot. Belg.
63: 108. 1931
).

Basidiomata large. Pileus 10.5–13.9 cm diam., plano-convex to applanate at maturity; volval remnants on pileus fibrillose to floccose or somewhat pulverulent, vivid yellow (3A8) to yellow (3B8), densely arranged on the disk; margin non-striate, appendiculate; context white (1A1), unchanging. Lamellae free, crowded, white (1A1); lamellulae attenuate with some subtruncate. Stipe 16.2–24.5× 1.8–2.1 cm , cylindrical and slightly tapering upwards, covered by vivid yellow (3A8) to yellow (3B8), floccose and somewhat pulverulent scales; context fistulose, white (1A1); basal part slightly inflated, fibrillose to floccose, light yellow (1A5) to vivid yellow (3A8) volval remnants. Annulus apical, fragile, sub-membranous, vivid yellow (3A8) to yellow (3B8). Odor not recorded.

Lamellar trama bilateral. Mediostratum 10–15 μm wide, composed of abundant sub-cylindrical inflated cells (40–62 × 8–15 μm); filamentous hyphae abundant to dominant, 1–10 μm wide; vascular hyphae scarce. Lateral stratum 15–23 μm wide, composed of abundant clavate to sub-cylindrical inflated cells (20–53 × 8–15 μm), diverging at an angle of ca. 30° to 45° to mediostratum; filamentous hyphae abundant, 2–7 μm wide. Subhymenium 15–25 μm thick, with 1–3 layers of subglobose, or irregular cells, 6–12 × 5–11 μm. Basidia ( Figure 4b ) 33–53 × 11–15 μm, clavate, 4-spored; sterigmata up to 3–4 μm long; basal septa lacking clamps. Basidiospores ( Figure 4a ) [50/2/2] (8) 8.5–10 (10.5) × 7–9 (9.5) μm, avl X avw = 9.1 × 8.4 μm, Q = 1.0–1.19 (1.29) μm, Qm = 1.09 ± 0.07, globose to subglobose, sometimes broadly ellipsoid, amyloid, colorless, guttulate, thin-walled, smooth; apiculus small. Pileipellis composed of radial, thin-walled, yellowish white, filamentous hyphae 3–18 μm wide; vascular hyphae scarce. Volval remnants on pileus ( Figure 4c ) composed of yellowish white, interwoven to repent arranged elements: filamentous hyphae fairly abundant, 2–9 μm wide, thin-walled, branching, anastomosing; inflated cells very abundant to dominant, slenderly clavate to fusiform, 18–165 × 10–40 μm, thin-walled; vascular hyphae scarce. Volval remnants on stipe base is semblable with the structure of volval remnants on pileus, filamentous hyphae scattered, 4–6 μm wide, thin-walled, branching, anastomosing; inflated cells very abundant to dominant, ellipsoid, clavate to sub-cylindrical, 23–200 × 18–35 μm, thin-walled; vascular hyphae scarce. Stipe trama composed of longitudinally arranged, filamentous hyphae, 5–15 μm wide; vascular hyphae scarce. Clamps absent in all parts of basidiomata..
Habitat: Solitary to scattered on soil in subtropical semi-deciduous seasonal forest, tropical deciduous forest, and on the ground along a road, in slightly sun-exposed areas, April to September.

Specimens examined: THAILAND . Chiang Rai Province : Mueang District , N 20°02’29’’ , E 99°49’47’’ , alt.
435 m
,

, Phongeun Sysouphanthong , PS-2020-38 (SDBR-STO-2020-PS38, GenBank accession no.: nrLSU =
OM 980704
, ITS = ON000811 , RPB2 = ON007281 , and
TEF1 -α
= ON007299 );
Phongeun Sysouphanthong, PS-2020- 39 (SDBR-STO-2020-PS39, GenBank accession No.: nrLSU =
OM 980705
, ITS = ON000812 , RPB2 = ON007282 , and
TEF1 -α
= ON007300 );
Chiang Mai Province : Mueang District , N 18°47’48’’ , E 98°57’11’’ , alt.
334 m
,

.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4.
Amanita aureofloccosa
(SDBR-STO-2020-PS38). a: Basidiospores. b: Hymenium and subhymenium. c: Longitudinal section of volval remnants on pileus. Bars: a=5 μm, b=20 μm, c=60 μm

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks: Morphologically,
Amanita aureofloccosa
is unique among congeners by having a pulverulent, bright orange-yellow volva remnant on its pileus, a slender stipe covered by orange-yellow floccose scales, a globose to subglobose, amyloid basidiospore and the lacking clamps in all parts of basidiomata. According to the original literature ( Bas 1969 ), the basidiospores size of
A. aureofloccosa
was described as 7–8.5 × 6.5–8.5 μm, but Wartcow et al . (2015) re-examined the lectotype (BR2229) and additional material from Ghana (K173243), and amended the basidiospores size to (6.5–) 6.8–10.5 (–10.8) × (6.5–) 6.8–10.2 (–10.5) μm, of which the results are similar to Thai material. Significantly, compared to the materials from other countries, our collections from Thailand have larger basidiomata and basidia.

paragraph.heading:
Amanita manicata (Berk. & Broome) Pegler, Kew Bull., Addit. Ser.
12: 216 (1986)
. Figure 1d

subSubSection.paragraph: Habitat: Solitary to scattered in black sand at berm of beach, on soil in grass or forest, in composted woodchips, April to October.
Distribution: Known from Dominican Republic , New Zealand , Sri Lanka , Thailand , and the USA (Hawaiian Islands) ( Petch 1910 ; Pegler 1986 ; Hemmes & Desjardin 2008 ).

Specimens examined: THAILAND . Chiang Rai Province : Mae Salong District , N 20°12’21” , E 99°41’12” , alt.
570 m
,
1Aug 2019
, Yuan S. Liu , STO-2019-347 (SDBR-STO-2019-347, GenBank accession no.: nrLSU =
OM 980706
, ITS = ON000813 , RPB2 = ON007283 , and
TEF1 -α
= ON007301 );
Chiang Mai Province : Sansai District , N 19°05’17” , E 98°58’43” , alt.
410 m
,
6 Aug 2019
, Yuan S. Liu , STO-2019-390 (SDBR-STO-2019-390, GenBank accession no.: nrLSU = ON692698 , ITS = ON692927 );
Chiang Mai Province : Mueang District , N 18°52’05” , E 98°56’42” , alt.
354 m
,
25 Jun 2020
, Yuan S. Liu , STO-2020-34 (SDBR-STO-2020-34, GenBank accession no.: nrLSU =
OM 980707
, ITS = ON000814 , RPB2 = ON007284 , and
TEF1 -α
= ON007302 );
Yuan S. Liu , STO-2020-36 (SDBR-STO-2020-36, GenBank accession no.: nrLSU =
OM 980708
, ITS = ON000815 , RPB2 = ON007285 , and
TEF1 -α
= ON007285 )
.

Remarks:
Amanita manicata
is characterized by its yellowish brown to pale tawny brown pileus covering with floccoso-verrucose to felty squamules; margin appendiculates with large floccose fragments which hang down up to 2 cm ; the cylindrical stipe covering with tawny brown floccoso-squamose which becomes more intense and thicker as upwards; the cream to whitish or pinkish tint lamellae; the subglobose and amyloid basidiospores (7.0–8.5 × 5.5–8.0 μm), as well as the present clamps. In our phylogenetic analysis,
A. manicata
closed to
A. flavofloccosa Nagas. & Hongo
,
A. foetidissima Reid & Eicker
and
A. nauseosa (Wakef.) Reid
and they formed a sister group ( Figure 2 ). Meanwhile, these four species share the similar appearance and color tone of basidioma, as well as the intense and unpleasant odor, which make people easily confuse for these species in the field. However,
A. flavofloccosa
can be distinguished from
A. manicata
by its yellow-brown to orange-yellow pileus and white, pinkish to yellowish lamellae (
Cui et al . 2018
).
Amanita foetidissima
, originally reported from South Africa ( Reid & Eicker 1991 ), has a pale creamy buff to buff pileus, oval to subglobose (7.0–9.0 × 6.2–8.0 μm), to broadly ellipsoid (9.0–10.0 × 6.0–6.2 μm) basidiospores, as well as the larger basidia (50.0–52.0 × 9.0–9.5 μm). Although
A. nauseosa
is very similar to
A. manicata
, it has a buff, or reddish-tinged to pale ochraceous buff surface and the greater basidiospores (7.0–9.0 × 6.5–8.0 μm) ( Bas 1969 ).

heading.emphasis:
Key to the Thai species of
Amanita sect. Lepidella

paragraph.keyLead:
1. Basidioma large; pileus golden yellow covering with fibrillose to floccoso or somewhat pulverulent, vivid yellow volval remnants; clamps absent; .........................................................................................................................................................
A. aureofloccosa

1. Basidioma small to very large; pileus white or pale tawny brown covering with fibrillose white scales or floccoso-verrucose to felty squamules; clamps present; .......................................................................................................................................................2

2. Basidioma large to very large, pileus yellowish brown to pale tawny brown; Annulus apical to subapical; basidiospores subglobose; .....................................................................................................................................................................
A. manicata

subSection.paragraph:
According to Bas (1969) , subsect. Vittadiniae comprises five stirps (stirps Hesleri , stirps
Nana
, stirps
Nauseosa
, stirps
Thiersii
and stirps
Vittadinii
).
Cui et al . (2018)
assigned stirps Hesleri and the rest four stirps to
A .
subgen.
Amanitina sect. Phalloideae
and
A .
subgen.
Lepidella sect. Lepidella
, respectively. In Bas’s monograph, species in stirps
Thiersii
can be firstly recognized on account of the absent clamp. Then species in stirps
Nauseosa
are characterized by their globose to broadly ellipsoid spores and lanose-floccose to floccose-squamulose and medially concentrated volval remnants on the stipe ( Bas 1969 ). Species in stirps
Nana
and stirps
Vittadinii
are characterized by having broadly ellipsoid to elongate spores and scattered or more rarely indistinct volval remnants on the stipe. Following above morphological characteristics, the novel species
A. albicarnosa
assigns to stirps
Vittadinii
,
A. aureofloccosa
and
A. manicata
separately match with stirps
Thiersii
and stirps
Nauseosa
. Meanwhile, our phylogenetic analysis almost entirely repeated Bas’s division in subsect. Vittadiniae . Our nrLSU-ITS phylogenetic analysis showed that there are five clades in subgen.
Lepidella
( Figure 2 ). The known species,
A. manicata
and our Thai new record,
A. aureofloccosa
were assigned to clade I and clade III, respectively. Clade II contains three species, namely
A. silvifuga
,
A . prairiocola
and
A. pleropus
. Clade II contains
A. codinae
and
A . vittadinii
(the type species of subgen. Lpidella and sect.
Lepidella
). The new species
A. albicarnosa
, coupling with
A. singeri
,
A. pruittii
,
A. quitensis
, and
A. inopinata
formed the basal taxa with well support values (clade V).

Summarizing, five clades in our phylogenetic analyses could respectively correspond with three stirps (stirps
Nauseosa
, stirps
Thiersii
and stirps
Vittadinii
) in Bas’s division. Under this relationship, clade II, clade IV and clade V well matched with stirps
Vittadinii
. Clade I and clade III well accorded with stirps
Nauseosa
and stirps
Thiersii
, respectively. It should be noted that the position of clade IV was not fixed probably because of the limited sequences. The distinct morphological differences and phylogenetic relationship indicate that
Amanita subgen. Lepidella
which contains a single section could be split into three or more sections.

This study is supported by the graduate school, Chiang Mai University. We appreciate Dr. Codjia Jean Evans I. (Kunming Institute of Botany, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Kunming, China ) for his valuable suggestions. This project is funded by the National Research Council of Thailand (no. N 42 A 650198).
